Award.AwardTitle: Group Travel Award: SCAR XIII International Symposium on Antarctic Earth Sciences: Korea, July 2019
Award.AbstractNarration:
The travel award supports US participation in the 13th Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR) International Symposium on Antarctic Earth Sciences (ISAES). Ten interdisciplinary themes are identified including solid earth and ice interactions, changes in the Southern Ocean, evolution of Antarctic life, and the history of the Antarctic Ice Sheets.

The project will provide partial support (airfare and meeting registration) for ~ 25 US participants enabling them to travel to Incheon, Republic of Korea and attend the SCAR International Symposium on Antarctic Earth Sciences in July 2019. Preference will be given to applicants who are students and early career scientists. The call for applications will be broadly disseminated to encourage participation by underrepresented groups in the sciences. ISAES is a unique opportunity for US scientists to present their work to an international community and address fundamental Antarctic Earth Science questions from an interdisciplinary perspective.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The United States is a member of the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR), an inter-disciplinary committee of the International Science Council. SCAR’s mission is to facilitate international scientific research in the Antarctic and the Southern Ocean. SCAR provides an important venue for international collaboration and coordination of research activities. In addition to an Open Science Conference every two years, SCAR organizes an international meeting for polar earth scientists every four years.

NSF funding provided partial travel support (airfare and meeting registration) for US participants to attend the XIIIth SCAR International Earth Sciences Symposium (ISAES) in Korea in July 2019. The Symposium covered exploration of all aspects of Antarctic and Southern Ocean geology and its linkages to glaciology, oceanography, biological sciences, and climatology. The SCAR ISAES is a unique opportunity for US scientists to 1) present their work, 2) learn about the most recent research projects and findings on all aspects of Antarctic earth sciences, 3) establish and strengthen international contacts and collaborations, and 4) be actively involved in the development of new directions and the establishment of new frontiers in polar science. The call for applications was broadly disseminated to encourage participation by underrepresented groups in the sciences. Travel awards were made to 24 US scientists from 16 institutions. Preference for travel awards was given to students and other early career scientists who would otherwise not have the means to attend an international meeting, these young scientists received 82% of the funds awarded.

Intellectual Merit. This grant promoted the exchange of information and ideas about polar science within the US and the international Antarctic scientific community by facilitating the attendance of US scientists to attend the XIIIth Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR) International Earth Sciences Symposium. There were a number of ancillary meetings and workshops held in conjunction with the Symposium, providing additional opportunities for US scientists to actively engage in international discussions.

Broader Impacts. Travel support for students and other young polar scientists enhanced their career development by providing the opportunity to learn about recent advances in Antarctic research, gain experience in presenting their own research results, and establish professional relationships with other polar scientists from the US and other countries. Attending an international meeting such as the SCAR Earth Sciences Symposium can be a catalytic experience for many young investigators and a significant event in their professional development and research careers.
